title-group.article-title: New Strain-Energy-Based Coupled Elastoplastic Two-Parameter Damage and Healing Models for Earth-Moving Processes

article-meta.aff: Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, University of California, Los Angeles, CA 90095, USA

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s), 2011. Reprints and permissions: www.sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Novel strain–energy-based coupled elastoplastic two-parameter damage and healing formulations for geomaterials are developed and implemented for a numerical simulation of two-dimensional earth-moving processes. A new class of elastoplastic damage–healing models is proposed within an initial-elastic strain–energy-based framework. The governing incremental damage and healing evolutions are coupled in volumetric and deviatoric parts and characterized through the effective stress concept. The plastic flow is established via an additive split of the stress tensor. Specifically, we introduce four characteristic energy norms of the tensile volumetric, tensile deviatoric, compressive volumetric, and compressive deviatoric strain tensors, respectively, for the corresponding volumetric and deviatoric damage and healing mechanisms. By adopting a micromechanics-motivated damage characterization (P+) and a healing characterization (P–) in the volumetric and deviatoric parts, the proposed two-parameter damage–healing models are implemented to demonstrate considerable versatility on numerical simulations of earth-moving processes. New computational algorithms are systematically developed based on the two-step operator splitting methodology. The volumetric and deviatoric elastic-damage–healing predictor and the effective plastic corrector are implemented within the Reproducing Kernel Particle Method (RKPM) meshfree codes. Numerical examples under earth excavation, transport, and compaction are presented to illustrate salient features of soils such as shear band and partial recovery of soil stiffness due to compaction by the new two-parameter damage–healing models.

kwd-group.kwd: coupled elastoplastic damage and healing models
volumetric and deviatoric damage and healing model

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Certain soil motions (such as rolling and gliding) can cause considerable amount of soil spillage during earth-moving processes, which decrease the soil-carrying capacity of earth-moving equipment and thus increase the costs of earthwork operations. These rolling and gliding motions also generate higher frictional contacts between the surfaces of soil particles and the equipment blades, leading to faster blade wear and higher energy consumption by the tractor (Xia, 2008). To enhance the operational efficiency of equipment, extensive laboratory experiments and field testing of competing designs for earth-moving equipment must be performed. To enable more economic and powerful design, a versatile computational framework that can be used to simulate soil motions during earth-moving activities is highly desired. Further, comprehensive physics-based material models of soils are needed in order to establish a rigorous computational framework to accommodate complex and instantaneous motions of cohesive soils.

Since the introduction of the scalar damage concept by Kachanov (1958) and Rabotnov (1963) for creep of metals, the continuum damage mechanics has become an emerging field of active research. Extensive phenomenological damage models were proposed in the literature. In particular, scalar damage variables were widely employed for isotropic or one-dimensional phenomenological damage models (Lemaitre, 1985); while vectorial, second-order, and fourth-order tensorial damage variables were often used for anisotropic phenomenological damage models (Kachanov, 1980; Simo and Ju, 1987a, b; Simo et al., 1988; Ju, 1989a, b, 1990; Simo and Ju, 1989; Ju et al., 2011a, b). However, there are few publications in coupled plasticity and sound damage models for cohesive soils. In particular, damage models are rarely built on two parts; that is, the volumetric and deviatoric parts. Aspointed out by Ju (1990), the scalar damage model implies that the Poisson’s ratio always remains a constant, and is therefore only a special case of the isotropic damage. Moreover, the general form of the fourth-order isotropic damage tensor consists of two parts: the volumetric and deviatoric components.

From different fields, some materials experimentally show that they can be repaired or healed in various manners such as chemical, physical, or biological phenomena, leading to progressive recovery of internal material defects. We refer to Barbero et al. (2005) for damage and irreversible deformation processes for a self-healing fiber-reinforced lamina. Further, literature review of self-healing materials can be found in Herbst and Luding (2008). However, there has been no published literature on rigorous formulations of damage and healing (recovery of elastic stiffness) models for granular cohesive soils, except the very recent work by Ju et al. (2011a, b). Nevertheless, the latter did not invoke the decomposition of damage tensors into the volumetric and deviatoric parts. Therefore, there is a fundamental need for physical and reliable modeling of the progressive coupled elastoplastic two-parameter damage and healing in cohesive granular soils under complex and cyclic loading during earth-moving processes.

The remainder of this article is organized as follows. New initial-elastic strain–energy-based coupled elastoplastic two-parameter damage–healing formulations are presented in the next section, following by brand new computational algorithms which are systematically developed based on the two-step operator splitting methodology. Numerical simulations of earth-moving processes are subsequently presented to illustrate the versatility and salient features of the proposed new two-parameter soil damage–healing models. The governing volumetric and deviatoric damage and healing evolutions are coupled in an incremental form and characterized through the effective stress concept in conjunction with the hypothesis of strain equivalence.

sec.title: NEW INITIAL-ELASTIC STRAIN–ENERGY-BASED COUPLED ELASTOPLASTIC TWO-PARAMETER DAMAGE AND HEALING MODELS
A Coupled Two-Parameter Formulation
sec.p: A crucial idea underlining the two-parameter coupled elastoplastic damage–healing models presented here concerns the criteria to determine when and how the individual volumetric or deviatoric, damage or healing mechanisms take place. In order to introduce the net effect of the volumetric and deviatoric damage–healing and plastic flow processes, a free-energy potential of the following form is proposed: (1) where εv≡13εkk1~ denotes the volumetric strain tensor; e is the deviatoric strain tensor; σp is the plastic relaxation stress tensor; q denotes a suitable set of internal (plastic) hardening variables. Here, d v net signifies the scalar variable of net (combined) effect of volumetric damage and healing, which depends on the volumetric damage variable dv, the incremental volumetric damage variable Δdv and the incremental volumetric healing variable ΔRv, all between 0 and 1 in numerical values. Similarly, d v net is the scalar variable of net (combined) effect of deviatoric damage and healing, which depends on the deviatoric damage variable dd, the incremental deviatoric damage variable Δdd and the incremental deviatoric healing variable ΔRd, all between 0 and 1 in numerical values. Moreover, Ψv 0(εv) defines the initial-elastic volumetric stored energy function of the undamaged material, Ψd 0(e) is the initial-elastic deviatoric stored energy function of the undamaged material, and Ξ(q,σp) is the plastic potential function. For the linear elasticity case, we have Ψv 0(εv)=12εv:(K1~⊗1~):εv=12K(εkk)2, where K denotes the bulk modulus; Ψd 0(e)=Ge:e, where G represents the shear modulus.

Confining our focus to the purely mechanical theory, the Clausius-Duhem (reduced dissipation) inequality (for purely mechanical isothermal theory) takes the form for any admissible process: (2)-Ψ·+σ:ε·≥0 By taking the time derivative of Equation (1), substituting it into Equation (2), and making use of standard arguments (Coleman and Gurtin, 1967) along with the additional assumption that the net effect of damage–healing and plastic unloading are elastic processes, we can obtain the stress–strain constitutive law (Ju, 1989a; Ju et al., 2011a): (3)σ=(1-d v net)∂Ψv 0(εv)∂εv+(1-d d net)∂Ψd 0(e)∂e-σp and the dissipative inequalities (4) (5)d·v netΨv 0(εv)+d·d netΨd 0(e)-∂Ξ(q,σp)∂q•q·-(∂Ξ(q,σp)∂σp-ε):σ·p≥0

It follows from Equation (3) that within the present strain–space formulation, the stress tensor is split into the volumetric and deviatoric elastic-damage–healing and the plastic relaxation parts. From Equations (4) and (5), we observe that the dissipative energy by plasticity itself is positive; if the damage–healing effect is involved, the sum of dissipative energy by the damage–healing and plasticity effect is also positive. It is clear from Equations (3), (4), and (5) that the present framework is capable of accommodating general (nonlinear) elastic response and general plastic response.

The potential Ξ(q,σp) is linked to plastic dissipation. Its role is such that inequality, Equation (5), is satisfied for arbitrary processes. Note that we have assumed that Ξ(q,σp) independent of dv net and dd net. From Equation (1), it then follows that: (6)-Yv≡-∂Ψ(εv,e,σp,q,d v net,d d net)∂d v net=Ψv 0(εv) (7)-Yd≡-∂Ψ(εv,e,σp,q,d v net,d d net)∂d d net=Ψd 0(e)

Hence, the initial (undamaged) volumetric elastic strain energy Ψv 0(εv) is the thermodynamic force Yv conjugate to the net volumetric damage–healing variable, d v net; the initial (undamaged) deviatoric elastic strain energy Ψd 0(e) is the thermodynamic force Yd conjugate to the net deviatoric damage–healing variable, d d net. Attention is then focused on the volumetric and deviatoric damage, the volumetric and deviatoric healing, and their interactions.

sec.title: Characterization of Initial-Elastic Strain–Energy-Based Two-Parameter Damage Model
sec.p: The proposed damage mechanism is called ‘two-parameter’ since the damage effects or evolutions are divided into the volumetric and deviatoric parts. Motivated by Equation (6), we first ascribe the notion of equivalent tensile volumetric strain ξv + as the (undamaged) energy norm of the tensile volumetric strain tensor: (8)ξv +≡Ψv 0(εv +)=12K(εkk +)2 where εkk +=ε11 ++ε22 ++ε33 + and ε+≡P+: ε. The ε tensor denotes the total strain, and the fourth-order tensor P+ denotes the ‘Mode I’ positive (tensile) projection tensor with components: (9)Pijkl +(ε)=12(Qik +Qjl ++Qil +Qjk +) where Q+≡∑i=1 2H∧(εi)pi⊗pi;ε=∑i=1 2εipi⊗pi,‖pi‖=1 for the two-dimensional (2D) simulations in this article. Here, εi is the ith principal strain, Pi is the ith corresponding unit vector in the principal direction, and H∧(εi) is the smoothed Heaviside function.
We then characterize the state of volumetric damage in soils by means of a volumetric damage criterion, φvd(ξv,t +,gv,t)≤0, formulated in the strain space, with the following form: (10)

Here, the subscript t refers to a value at current time, t∈ℜ+, and gv,t is the volumetric damage threshold at the current time t. The numerical value of gv,t would be lowered due to the incremental volumetric healing (if any) from the previous time step. Let gv,0 denote the initial volumetric damage threshold before any loading is applied; we must have gv,t ≥ gv,0. Here, gv,0 is considered to be a characteristic material property. Equation (10) then states that volumetric damage in soils is initiated when the energy norm of the tensile volumetric strain ξv,t + exceeds the initial volumetric damage threshold gv,0. We define the evolution of the volumetric damage variabledv,t and the volumetric damage threshold gv,t, respectively, by the rate equations: (11)d·v,t=μ·vHv(ξv,t +,d v,t) (12)g·v=μ·v where μ·v≥0 is the volumetric damage consistency parameter that defines the volumetric damage loading/unloading conditions according to the Kuhn-Tucker relations: (13)

Moreover, Hv in Equation (11) denotes the volumetric damage-hardening function. Equation (13) is standard for problems involving unilateral constraint. If φvd(ξv,t +,gv,t)<0, the volumetric damage criterion is not satisfied and by Equation (13), μ·v=0; hence, the volumetric damage rule, Equation (11), implies that d·v=0 and no further volumetric damage takes place. If,on the other hand, μ·v>0; that is, further volumetric damage (‘tensile loading’) is taking place. Equation (13) implies that φvd(ξv,t +,gv,t)=0. In this event, the value of μ·v is determined by the volumetric damage consistency condition; that is: (14) and gv,t is defined by the expression: (15)gv,t=max(gv,0,maxs∈(-∞,t)ξv,s +)- gvh,(t-1) where gvt,(t – 1) defines the reduced value for the current volumetric damage threshold due to incremental volumetric healing (if any) from the previous time step.

If Hv(ξv,t +,d v,t) in Equation (11) is independent of d·v,t, the above formulation may be rephrased as follows. Let Gv:ℜ→ℜ+ be such that Hv(ξv,t +)≡∂Gv(ξv,t +)/∂ξv,t +. We assume that Gv(•) is monotonic. A volumetric damage criterion entirely equivalent to Equation (10) is given by φ¯v d(ξv,t +,gv,t)≡Gv(ξv,t +)-Gv(gv,t)≤0. The flow rule and loading/unloading conditions become: (16)d·v,t=μ·v∂φ¯v d(ξv,t +,gv,t)∂ξv,t +, gv,t=μ·v (17)μ·v≥0, φ¯v d(ξv,t +,gv,t)≤0, μ·vφ¯v d(ξv,t +,gv,t)=0
Equations (16) and (17) are simply the Kuhn-Tucker optimality conditions of a principle of maximum damage dissipation.

Likewise, we ascribe the notion of equivalent tensile deviatoric strain ξd + as the (undamaged) energy norm of the tensile deviatoric strain tensor. Motivated by Equation (7), we define: (18)ξd +≡Ψd 0(e+)=12Ge+:e+ where e+=ε+-13εkk +1~ and ε+≡P+:ε.

Similar to the characterization of volumetric damage, we can characterize the state of deviatoric damage by means of a deviatoric damage criterion φdd(ξd,t +,gd,t)≤0, formulated in the strain space, with the following functional form: (19)

Here, the subscript t refers to a value at the current time, t∈ℜ+, and gd,t is the deviatoric damage threshold at the current time t. It is noted that gd,t will be lowered in value due to the incremental deviatoric healing from the previous time step. If gd,0 denotes the initial deviatoric damage threshold before any loading is applied, we must have gd,t ≥ gd,0. Note that gd,0 is considered as a characteristic material property. Equation (19) states that deviatoric damage in soils is initiated when the energy norm of the tensile deviatoric strain tensor ξd,t + exceeds the initial deviatoric damage threshold gd,0. We define the evolution of the deviatoric damage variable dd,t and the deviatoric damage threshold gd,t by the rate equations: (20)d·d,t=μ·dHd(ξd,t +,d d,t) (21)g·d=μ·d where μ·d≥0 is the deviatoric damage consistency parameter that defines deviatoric damage loading/unloading conditions according to the Kuhn-Tucker relations: (22)

Moreover, Hd in Equation (20) signifies the deviatoric damage-hardening function. Equation (22) is standard for problems involving unilateral constraint. If φdd(ξd,t +,gd,t)<0, the deviatoric damage criterion is not satisfied and by Equation (22), μ·d=0; hence, the deviatoric damage rule, Equation (20), implies that d·d=0 and no further deviatoric damage takes place. If, on the other hand, μ·d>0; that is, further deviatoric damage (‘tensile loading’) is taking place, Equation (22) implies that φdd(ξd,t +,gd,t)=0. In this case, the value of μ·d is determined by the deviatoric damage consistency condition; that is: (23) and gd,t is defined by the expression: (24)gd,t=max(gd,0,maxs∈(-∞,t)ξd,s +)-gdh,(t-1) where gdh,(t – 1) is the value for the current deviatoric damage threshold to be numerically reduced due to incremental deviatoric healing (if any) from the previous time step.

If Hd(ξd,t +,d d,t) in Equation (20) is independent of d·d,t, the above formulation may be rephrased as follows. Let Gd:ℜ→ℜ+ be such that Hd(ξd,t +)≡∂Gd(ξd,t +)/∂ξd,t +. We assume that Gd(•) is monotonic. A deviatoric damage criterion entirely equivalent to Equation (19) is given by φ¯d d(ξd,t +,gd,t)≡Gd(ξd,t +)-Gd(gd,t)≤0. The flow rule and loading/unloading conditions read: (25)d·d,t=μ·d∂φ¯d d(ξd,t +,gd,t)∂ξd,t +, gd,t=μ·d (26)μ·d≥0, φ¯d d(ξd,t +,gd,t)≤0, μ·dφ¯d d(ξd,t +,gd,t)=0

sec.title: Characterization of Initial-Elastic Strain–Energy-Based Two-Parameter Healing Model
sec.p: Similar to the characterization of volumetric and deviatoric damage in the previous section, we characterize the progressive recovery of mechanical properties of soils due to healing by means of a two-parameter-healing mechanism. Here, we use the notion of equivalent compressive volumetric strain ξv - as the energy norm of the compressive volumetric strain tensor. Accordingly, we set: (27)ξv -≡Ψv 0(εv -)=12K(εkk -)2 where εkk -=ε11 -+ε22 -+ε33 - and ε– ≡ P–:ε. The fourth-order tensor P– denotes the ‘Mode I’ negative (compressive) projection tensor with components: (28)Pijkl -(ε)=12(Qik -Qjl -+Qil -Qjk -) where Q-=1~-Q+.
We now define a volumetric criterion φvh(ξv,t -,rv,t)≤0, formulated in the strain space, with the following functional form: (29)

Here, rv,t defines the volumetric healing threshold at the current time t. If rv,0 denotes the initial volumetric healing threshold before any loading is applied, we must have rv,t ≥ rv,0. Note that rv,0 is considered as a characteristic material property. Equation (29) then states that volumetric healing in the material is initiated when the energy norm of the compressive volumetric strain tensor ξv,t - exceeds the initial volumetric healing threshold rv,0. We define the evolution of the volumetric healing variable Rv and the volumetric healing threshold rv,t by the rate equations: (30)R·v,t=ζ·vZv(ξv,t -,Rv,t) (31)r·v=ζ·v where ζ·v≥0 is a volumetric healing consistency parameter that defines the volumetric healing loading/unloading conditions according to the Kuhn-Tucker relations: (32)

Moreover, Zv in Equation (30) stands for the volumetric healing hardening function. Equation (32) is standard for problems involving unilateral constraint. If φvh(ξv,t -,rv,t)<0, the volumetric healing criterion is not satisfied and Equation (32), ζ·v=0; hence, the volumetric healing rule, Equation (30), implies that R·v=0 and no further volumetric healing takes place. If, on the other hand, ζ·v>0, that is, further volumetric healing (‘compressive loading’) is taking place, Equation (32) implies that φvh(ξv,t -,rv,t)=0. In this event, the value of ζ·v is determined by the volumetric healing consistency condition; that is: (33) and rv,t is given by the expression: (34)rv,t=max(rv,0,maxs∈(-∞,t)ξv,s -)-rvd,(t-1) where rvd,(t – 1) is the value for the current volumetric healing threshold to be reduced due to the incremental volumetric damage (if any) from the previous time step.

If Zv(ξv,t -,Rv,t) in Equation (30) is independent of R·v,t, the above formulation may be rephrased as follows. Let Gv *:ℜ→ℜ+ be such that Zv(ξv,t -)≡∂Gv *(ξv,t -)/∂ξv,t -. We assume that Gv *(•) is monotonic. A volumetric healing criterion entirely equivalent to Equation (29) is given by φ¯v h(ξv,t -,rv,t)≡Gv *(ξv,t -)-G*(rv,t)≤0. The flow rule and loading/unloading conditions become: (35)R·v,t=ζ·v∂φ¯v h(ξv,t -,rv,t)∂ξv,t -, rv,t=ζ·v (36)ζ·v≥0, φ¯v h(ξtv -,rtv)≤0, ζ·vφ¯v h(ξtv -,rtv)=0

Next, we ascribe the notion of equivalent compressive deviatoric strain ξd - as the (undamaged) energy norm of the compressive deviatoric strain tensor. We define: (37)ξd -≡Ψd 0(e-)=12Ge-:e- where e-=ε--13εkk -1~ and ε– ≡ P–:ε. We then characterize the state of deviatoric healing by using a deviatoric healing criterion φdh(ξd,t -,rd,t)≤0, formulated in the strain space, with the following functional form: (38)

Here, rd,t is the deviatoric healing threshold at the current time t. If rd,0 denotes the initial deviatoric healing threshold before any loading is applied, we must have rd,t ≥ rd,0. Note that rd,0 is also considered as a characteristic material property. Equation (38) then states that deviatoric healing in the material is initiated when the energy norm of the compressive deviatoric strain tensor ξd,t - exceeds the initial deviatoric healing threshold rd,0. For the case, we define the evolution of the deviatoric healing variable Rd and the deviatoric healing threshold rd,t by the rate equations: (39)R·d,t=ζ·dZd(ξd,t -,Rd,t) (40)r·d=ζ·d where ζ·d≥0 is a deviatoric healing consistency parameter that defines deviatoric healing loading/unloading conditions according to the Kuhn-Tucker relations: (41)

Moreover, Zd in Equation (39) represents the deviatoric healing hardening function. Equation (41) is standard for problems involving unilateral constraint. If φdh(ξd,t -,rd,t)<0, the deviatoric healing criterion is not satisfied and by Equation (41), ζ·d=0; hence, the deviatoric healing rule, Equation (39), implies that R·d=0 and no further deviatoric healing takes place. By contrast, if ζ·d>0, further deviatoric healing (‘compressive loading’) takes place and Equation (41) implies that φdh(ξd,t -,rd,t)=0. In this event, the value of ζ·d is determined by the deviatoric healing consistency condition; that is: (42) and rd,t is given by the expression: (43)rd,t=max(rd,0,maxs∈(-∞,t)ξd,s -)- rdd,(t-1) where rdd,(t – 1) is the numerically reduced value for the current deviatoric healing threshold due to the incremental deviatoric damage (if any) from the previous time step.

If Zd(ξd,t -,Rd,t) in Equation (39) is independent of R·d,t, the above formulation may be rephrased as follows. Let Gd *:ℜ→ℜ+ be such that Zd(ξd,t -)≡∂Gd *(ξd,t -)/∂ξd,t -. We assume that Gd *(•) is monotonic. A deviatoric healing criterion entirely equivalent to Equation (38) is given by φ¯d h(ξd,t -,rd,t)≡Gd *(ξd,t -)-G*(rd,t)≤0. The flow rule and loading/unloading conditions become: (44)R·d,t=ζ·d∂φ¯d h(ξd,t -,rd,t)∂ξd,t -, rd,t=ζ·d (45)ζ·d≥0, φ¯d h(ξd,t -,rd,t)≤0, ζ·dφ¯d h(ξd,t -,rd,t)=0

sec.title: Net (Combined) Effects of the Two-Parameter Damage and Healing Models
sec.p: In our recent work (Ju et al., 2011a, b), we clearly illustrated that the following characterization for the net effects of damage and healing is physically incorrect and misleading: (46)d net=d(1-R)
We then proposed a micromechanics-motivated scalar incremental form to compute the net effects of isotropic damage–healing, dnet, as expressed in Equation (33) of Ju et al. (2011a).

As for the net effects of two-parameter damage–healing mechanisms, we propose to have two independent variables (the volumetric variable d v net and the deviatoric variable d d net). The following interacting mechanisms are proposed: (47) where Δdv,n+1 is the incremental volumetric damage variable; Δd d,n+1 means the incremental deviatoric damage variable; d∧v,n+1 is defined as the interim volumetric damage variable; d∧d,n+1 is the interim deviatoric damage variable; Δd v,n+1 h represents the incremental volumetric recovery due to theincremental volumetric healing; Δd d,n+1 h signifies the incremental deviatoric recovery due to the incremental deviatoric healing. Take the volumetric part for instance, if there is no volumetric healing, the interim volumetric damage variable d∧v,n+1 is equal to d v,n+1 net. If the volumetric healing exists, the net (combined) volumetric damage–healing variable d v,n+1 net must be modified by Δd v,n+1 h.
With Δd v net and Δd d net known, the incremental fourth-rank damage tensor can be obtained by the following equation: (48)ΔD=Δd v net1~⊗1~+Δd d netIdev

sec.title: COMPUTATIONAL ALGORITHMS: TWO-STEP OPERATOR SPLITTING
sec.p:
In the previous sections, we have developed the new initial elastic strain–energy-based two-parameter damage–healing models based on the effective stress concept. In this section, we focus in detail on the computational aspects of the proposed new damage–healing models within the context of two-step operator splitting methodology. More precisely, the attention is placed on the following local two-parameter elastoplastic damage–healing rate constitutive equations:
(49) (50)

From an algorithmic standpoint, the problem of integrating the evolution Equations (49) and (50) reduce to updating the basic variables {σ,d v net,d d net,σ¯p,q} in a manner consistent with the constitutive models. It is essential to realize that in this computational process the history of strains t→ε≡∇su(t) is assumed to be given.

Equations of evolution are to be solved incrementally over a sequence ofgiven time steps [tn,tn+1]⊂R+, n=0,1,2…. Therefore, the initial conditions for equations are: {σ,d v net,d d net,σ¯p,q}|t=tn={σn,d v,n net,d d,n net,σ¯n p,qn}

In accordance with the notion of operator split, we consider the followingadditive decomposition of problem of evolution into the elastic-damage–healing predictor and the plastic corrector parts. (51) (52)

It is noted that Equations (51) and (52) do indeed add up to Equations (49) and (50), in agreement with the notion of operator split. The formulation of an algorithm consistent with equations is based on the following fundamental result concerning operator split method. Given the two algorithms, the first one is consistent with Equation (51) (the elastic-damage–healing predictor) and the second one is consistent with Equation (52) (the plastic return mapping corrector). In turn, the product algorithm obtained by successive application of these two algorithms is consistent with the original problem.

sec.title: The Two-Parameter Elastic-Damage–Healing Predictor
sec.p: An algorithm consistent with Equations (51) and (52), referred to as the two-parameter elastic-damage–healing predictor, is rendered by the following step-by-step procedure.
Step 1: Strain update: Given the incremental displacement field un + 1, the strain tensor is updated as: εn+1=εn+∇sun+1.

Step 2: Compute the ‘Mode I positive fourth-rank projection operator’ (different from Simo and Ju, 1987a, b; Ju, 1989a, b), based on the total strain tensor εn + 1: (53)Pijkl +(εn+1)=12(Qik +Qjl ++Qil +Qjk +) where Qn+1 +=∑i=1 2H∧(εi)pi⊗pi;εn+1=∑i=1 2εipi⊗pi (for 2D simulations in this article) and H∧(εi) is the smoothed Heaviside function.
Step 3: Compute the ‘negative fourth-rank projection operator’ based on the total strain tensor εn + 1: (54)Pijkl -(εn+1)=12(Qik -Qjl -+Qil -Qjk -) where Qn+1 -=1~-Qn+1 +.

Step 4: Compute the initial (undamaged) elastic tensile and compressive volumetric and deviatoric strain energies, ξv,n+1 +,ξd,n+1 +,ξv,n+1 -and ξd,n+1 -. (55)ξv,n+1 +≡Ψv 0(εv,n+1 +)=12K(εkk,n+1 +)2, iflinearelasticity (56)ξd,n+1 +≡Ψd 0(en+1 +)=12Gen+1 +:en+1 + (57)ξv,n+1 -≡Ψv 0(εv,n+1 -)=12K(εkk,n+1 -)2, iflinearelasticity (58)ξd,n+1 -≡Ψd 0(en+1 -)=12Gen+1 -:en+1 - where εkk +=ε11 ++ε22 ++ε33 +, e+=ε+-13εkk +1~, ε+=P+:ε and ε-=P-:ε.
Step 5: Update the two scalar damage parameter thresholds (d~v)n+1and(d~d)n+1.
For the volumetric part:
(a) If (ΔRv)n>0 and (d~v)n>0, update the volumetric damage parameter threshold: (59)(d~v)n+1=(d~v)n(1.0-(ΔRv)n)
(b) Otherwise, set: (60)(d~v)n+1=(d~v)n
For the deviatoric part:
(a) If (ΔRd)n>0 and (d~d)n>0, update the deviatoric damage parameter threshold: (61)(d~d)n+1=(d~d)n(1.0-(ΔRd)n)
(b) Otherwise, set: (62)(d~d)n+1=(d~d)n

Step 6: Compute the two scalar damage predictors (d v)n+1 and (d d)n+1. Define: UBVD
the upper bound of the volumetric damage threshold (0 < UBVD < 1). ξUBVD +
the upper bound of tensile volumetric strain energy obtained from the volumetric damage functional evaluation for specific UBVD. UBDD
the upper bound of deviatoric damage threshold (0 < UBDD < 1). ξUBDD +
the upper bound of tensile deviatoric strain energy.
For the volumetric part:
(a) If ξv,n+1 +≤ξvol 0+, no further volumetric damage, set Δ(d v)n+1=0, where ξvol 0+ is the initial volumetric damage threshold.

(b) If ξvol 0+ < ξv,n+1 + < ξUBVD +, compute (d v)n+1 using a nonlinear damage functional evaluation, such as one of the following two functions (Wu, 2005): (63)(d v)n+1(ξv,n+1 +)=(kv)c [ξv,n+1 +-(kv)i]ξv,n+1 +[(kv)c-(kv)i] where (kv)c and (kv)i are material constants for the volumetric damage evolution. (64)(d v)n+1(ξv,n+1 +)=1-Av(1-Bv)ξv,n+1 +-Bvexp[Av-ξv,n+1 +] where Av and Bv are material constants for the volumetric damage evolution.
(c) If ξv,n+1 +≥ξUBVD +, set (d v)n+1=UBVD and a counter Nv. If Nv > 1, no further volumetric damage, set Δ(d v)n+1=0.
For the deviatoric part:
(a) If ξd,n+1 +≤ξdev 0+, no further deviatoric damage, set Δ(d d)n+1=0, where ξdev 0+ is the initial deviatoric damage threshold.

(b) ξdev 0+ < ξd,n+1 + < ξUBDD +, compute (d d)n+1 using a nonlinear damage functional evaluation, such as one of the following two functions (Wu, 2005): (65)(d d)n+1(ξd,n+1 +)=(kd)c [ξd,n+1 +-(kd)i]ξd,n+1 +[(kd)c-(kd)i] (66)(d d)n+1(ξd,n+1 +)=1-Ad(1-Bd)ξd,n+1 +-Bdexp[Ad-ξd,n+1 +]
(c) If ξd,n+1 +≥ξUBDD +, set (d d)n+1=UBDD and a counter Nd. If Nd > 1, no further deviatoric damage, set Δ(d d)n+1=0.
If both Δ(d v)n+1=0 and Δ(d d)n+1=0, go to Step 10.
Step 7: Check the two incremental scalar damage criteria Δ(d v)n+1 and Δ(d d)n+1: (67)Δ(d v)n+1=(d v)n+1-(d~v)n+1 (68)Δ(d d)n+1=(d d)n+1-(d~d)n+1
If Δξn+1 +≤0, then set Δ(d v)n+1=0 and Δ(d d)n+1=0.
Only when both Δ(d v)n+1≤0 and Δ(d d)n+1≤0, go to Step 10.
Otherwise, if Δ(d v)n+1>0, set (d~v)n+1=(d v)n+1; continue.
If Δ(d d)n+1>0, set (d~d)n+1=(d d)n+1; continue
where (d~v)n and (d~d)n denote the scalar volumetric and deviatoric damage parameter thresholds from the previous time step.

Step 8: Compute the incremental two-parameter damage predictor tensor ΔDn+1 and the updated nonsymmetric interim two-parameter damage tensor D∧n+1: (69)ΔDn+1=(Δd v)n+11~⊗1~+(Δd d)n+1Idev (70)D∧n+1=Dn net+ΔDn+1
Step 9: Update the two scalar healing parameter thresholds (R~v)n+1and (R~d)n+1:
(R~v)n+1and (R~d)n+1 denote the net amount of volumetric and deviatoric healing sustained after damage takes place.
(a) If (Δd v)n+1>0 and (R~v)n>0, update the volumetric healing threshold for next step: (71)(R~v)n+1=(R~v)n(1.0-(Δd v)n+1)
(b) Otherwise, set: (72)(R~v)n+1=(R~v)n
(a) If (Δd d)n+1>0 and (R~d)n>0, update the deviatoric healing threshold for next step: (73)(R~d)n+1=(R~d)n(1.0-(Δd d)n+1)
(b) Otherwise, set: (74)(R~d)n+1=(R~d)n

Step 10: Compute the two scalar healing predictors (Rv)n+1 and (Rd)n+1. Define: UBVH
the upper bound of the volumetric healing threshold (0 < UBVH < 1). ξUBVH -
the upper bound of compressive volumetric strain energy obtained from the volumetric healing functional evaluation for specific UBVH (set as 0.6, for example). UBDH
the upper bound of the deviatoric healing threshold (0 < UBDH < 1). ξUBDH -
the upper bound of compressive deviatoric strain energy obtained from the deviatoric damage functional evaluation for specific UBDH (set as 0.6, for example).
(a) If ξv,n+1 -≤ξvol 0-, no further volumetric healing, set Δ(Rv)n+1=0
where ξvol 0- is the initial volumetric healing threshold.

(b) If ξvol 0- < ξv,n+1 - < ξUBVH -, compute (Rv)n+1 using a nonlinear healing functional evaluation, such as the following function (Wu, 2005): (75)(Rv)n+1(ξv,n+1 -)=(hv)c[ξv,n+1 --(hv)i]ξv,n+1 -[(hv)c-(hv)i]
where (hv)c and (hv)i are material constants for the volumetric healing evolution.
Or, use the following function: (76)(2)(Rv)n+1(ξv,n+1 -)=1-A¯v(1-B¯v)ξv,n+1 --B¯vexp[A¯v-ξv,n+1 -]
(c) where A¯v and B¯v are material constants for volumetric healing evolution.
If ξv,n+1 -≥ξUBVH -, set (Rv)n+1=UBVH and a counter Mv.
If Mv > 1, no further volumetric healing, set Δ(Rv)n+1=0
(a) If ξd,n+1 -≤ξdev 0-, no further deviatoric healing, set Δ(Rd)n+1=0
where ξdev 0- is the initial deviatoric healing threshold.

(b) If ξdev 0- < ξd,n+1 - < ξUBDH -, compute (Rd)n+1 using a nonlinear healing functional evaluation, such as the following function (Wu, 2005): (77)(1)(Rd)n+1(ξd,n+1 -)=(hd)c [ξd,n+1 --(hd)i]ξd,n+1 -[(hd)c-(hd)i]
where (hd)c and (hd)i are material constants for the deviatoric healing evolution. (78)(2)(Rd)n+1(ξd,n+1 -)=1-A¯d(1-B¯d)ξd,n+1 --B¯dexp[A¯d-ξd,n+1 -]
where A¯d and B¯d are material constants for deviatoric healing evolution.
(c) If ξd,n+1 -≥ξUBDH -, set (Rd)n+1=UBDH and a counter Md.
If Md > 1, no further deviatoric healing, set Δ(Rd)n+1=0.
Only when both Δ(Rv)n+1=0 and Δ(Rd)n+1=0, go to Step 14.
Otherwise, go to Step 11.
Step 11: Check the two incremental scalar healing criteria Δ(Rv)n+1 and Δ(Rd)n+1: (79)Δ(Rv)n+1=(Rv)n+1-(R~v)n+1 (80)Δ(Rd)n+1=(Rd)n+1-(R~d)n+1
If Δξn+1 -≤0, then set Δ(Rv)n+1=0 and Δ(Rd)n+1=0.
Only when both Δ(Rv)n+1≤0 and Δ(Rd)n+1≤0, go to Step 14.
Otherwise, if Δ(Rv)n+1>0, set (R~v)n+1=(Rv)n+1; continue.
If Δ(Rd)n+1>0, set (R~d)n+1=(Rd)n+1; continue.
where (R~v)n and (R~d)n denote the scalar volumetric and deviatoric healing parameter thresholds from the previous time step.
Step 12: Compute the two-parameter incremental healing tensor ΔRn+1: ΔRn+1=(ΔRv)n+11~⊗1~+(ΔRd)n+1Idev
Step 13: Compute the incremental healing corrector, and update the two-parameter net (combined) damage – healing tensor: (82)ΔDn+1 H=-D∧n+1•ΔRn+1 Dn+1 net=D∧n+1+ΔDn+1 H
Trial (predictor) stress: By substitution into the potential for the stress tensor, we obtain: (83)σn+1 0=∂Ψ0(εn+1)∂εσ¯n+1 trial=σn+1 0-σ¯n pqn+1 trial=qn

A flow chart is exhibited in Figure 1 to demonstrate the computational algorithms for the proposed new two-parameter model from Step 5 to Step13. Figure 1.
A flow chart of the computational algorithms for the two-parameter models (from Step 5 to Step 13).

sec.title: The Effective Plastic Return Mapping Corrector
sec.p: To develop an algorithm consistent with the plastic part of the operator split, one first checks the loading/unloading conditions.
Step 14: Check plastic yielding and active mode:

The algorithmic counterpart of the Kuhn-Tucker conditions is trivially implemented in terms of the elastic-damage trial stress. One simply checks: (84)
Multisurface plasticity: In the case of plastic loading, it is necessary to determine the active plastic surface, such as the cap model.

Step 15: Effective plastic return mapping corrector:
In the event of plastic loading, the predictor stresses and internal variables are ‘returned back’ to the yield surface along the algorithmic counterpart of the flow generated by Equation (53). The algorithmic construction of this flow follows a proposed procedure inspired by a form of Kelley’s convex cutting plane method for nonlinear optimization, with its basic structure inherited from the Newton’s method. Two fundamental advantages of this procedure are: (a) the quadratic rate of convergence toward the yield surface and (b) theneed for computing the gradient of the flow rule and hardening law are bypassed.
Step 16: Update the homogenized (nominal) stress σn+1: (85)σn+1=[I-Dn+1 net]:σ¯n+1

sec.title: NUMERICAL SIMULATIONS OF SOIL COMPRESSION, EXCAVATION, AND COMPACTION MOTIONS
sec.p:
In order to demonstrate that the new two-parameter elastoplastic damage–healing models can generate more versatile simulations than the hybrid isotropic elastoplastic damage–healing models proposed in our previous work (Ju et al., 2011a, b), the same numerical examples of soil compression, excavation, and compaction are performed to render a fair comparison. The associated soil properties are listed in Table 1; cf. Wu (2005). The Drucker-Prager associative multisurface plasticity formulation is employed to model the soil behavior for simplicity; cf. Simo et al. (1988), Wu et al. (2001), and Chen et al. (2009). Table 1.
The associated soil properties.
Young’s modulus 24.7 (MPa)
Poisson’s ratio 0.35
Density 1.88 × 103 (kg/m3)
Cohesion 0.19 (MPa)
Lame constants λ = 2.13457 × 107 (Pa)
µ = 9.14815 × 107 (Pa)
Yield stress 1.88312 × 105 (Pa)

The initial configuration and discretization of the earth-moving process is exhibited in Figure 2. The blade of the bulldozer is treated as a rigid body and thus represented by two contact surfaces in black color. To model the contact between soil particles and blade surfaces, the traditional penalty formulation is adopted. A layer of soil with dimension 4 × 2 m is discretized into 41 × 21 = 861 uniformly distributed particles. As an important extension of semi-Lagrangian discretization, a new particle-based ‘partition of unity’ contact algorithm was developed (Wu, 2005). The natural contact algorithm (Wu, 2005) is applied to model the contact between soil particles and ground surfaces, which is found on the right-hand side in Figure 2. The blade in Figure 2 is controlled to move horizontally to the right for 0.3 m, lift the soil vertically for 3 m, move horizontally to the right for 1.8 m, rotate 45 degrees to dump the soil over the wall and then rotate back to move forward and downward to compact the soil in the ground pit. Figure 2.
The initial configuration and discretization of the earth-moving process.

For the new two-parameter elastoplastic damage–healing models, in addition to the material parameters in damage and healing evolutions, there are four more material parameters to control the soil behavior under complex numerical simulations. These include the initial volumetric damage threshold ξvol 0+, initial deviatoric damage threshold ξdev 0+, initial volumetric healing threshold ξvol 0-, and initial deviatoric healing threshold ξdev 0-. In the numerical simulations, the following two assumptions are made for simplicity. (i) The soil complies with the volumetric and deviatoric damage – healing evolutions as described in Equations (63), (65), (75), and (77). (ii) The volumetric and deviatoric damage–healing evolutions use the same material parameters; that is, (kv)c=(kd)c=(hv)c=(hd)c=0.05 and (kv)i=(kd)i=(hv)i=(hd)i=50 for ductile soils.

Subsequently, a parametric study is performed to compare the new two-parameter damage–healing models with the previous hybrid isotropic damage–healing model, as rendered in Table 2, on the initial volumetric damage threshold, the initial deviatoric damage threshold, the initial volumetric healing threshold, and the initial deviatoric healing threshold. Table 2.
A parametric study on ξvol 0+, ξdev 0+, ξvol 0-, and ξdev 0-.
Initial volumetric damage threshold Initial deviatoric damage threshold Initial volumetric healing threshold Initial deviatoric healing threshold
ξvol 0+ ξdev 0+ ξvol 0- ξdev 0-
Hybrid isotropic elastoplastic damage–healing model
0.050 0.050 0.080 0.080
Two-parameter elastoplastic damage–healing models
Effect of volumetric damage 0.040 0.050 infinite infinite
0.045
0.055
0.060
Effect of deviatoric damage 0.050 0.040 infinite infinite
0.045
0.055
0.060
Effect of volumetric healing 0.050 0.050 0.070 0.080
0.075
0.085
0.090
Effect of deviatoric healing 0.050 0.050 0.080 0.070
0.075
0.085
0.090

Table 2 clearly shows that while the hybrid isotropic elastoplastic damage and healing models can generate only one numerical simulation in our previous work (Ju etal., 2011a, b), the new two-parameter elastoplastic damage and healing models can have multiple versatile combinations of numerical simulations by slightly adjusting ξvol 0+, ξdel 0+, ξvol 0-, and ξdev 0- for the underlying soil compression, excavation, and compaction operations.

In this section, we present select numerical results to illustrate the salient features and versatile simulation capability of the proposed damage–healing models. Furthermore, the comparisons of progressive deformations at various time steps for the effects of initial deviatoric damage threshold are displayed in Figure 3, and for the effects of initial volumetric and deviatoric healing thresholds are rendered in Figure 4. In these figures, the blue solid circles represent the soil particles with no volumetric (deviatoric) damage, the red solid circles symbolize the soil particles with full volumetric (deviatoric) damage (the upper bound damage UBVD and UBDD in these simulations), and the solid circles in other colors (such as green, yellow and orange) signify partial volumetric (deviatoric) damage between 0 and the upper bound damage. Figure 3.
A parametric study on the initial deviatoric damage threshold ξdev 0+ (ξvol 0+=0.05,ξvol 0-=ξdev 0-=infinite) of deformation of soils for various stages of the earth-moving simulations by the two-parameter damage–healing models. Figure 4.
A parametric study on the initial volumetric and deviatoric healing thresholds (ξvol 0-, ξdev 0-) (ξvol 0+=ξdev 0+=0.05) of deformation of soils for various stages of the earth-moving simulations by the two-parameter damage–healing models.

sec.title: CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: In this article, new initial-elastic strain–energy-based coupled elastoplastic two-parameter damage–healing formulations have been presented for the simulations of complex earth-moving processes. The equivalent strain based on P+ and P– in volumetric and deviatoric parts for energy criteria of the volumetric and deviatoric damage and healing are employed for the proposed new models. Innovative two-step operator split algorithms are presented, featuring the volumetric and deviatoric elastic-damage–healing predictors and the effective plastic return mapping corrector. In addition, the coupling of the volumetric and deviatoric damage and healing mechanisms is characterized in an incremental form by using the predictor formula and corrector formula. In the absence of associated experimental data, the proposed two-parameter innovative formulations and algorithms for soils only illustrate their significant versatility and the salient damage–healing features. Experimental validations for the key parameters in damage and healing evolutions will be performed once the associated experiment data becomes available. Fully saturated soils are considered in this article. The effects of moisture and matric suction for partially saturated soils will be considered in a forthcoming article. Further, extension of the current work can be made to accommodate the fourth-rank anisotropic damage–healing formulations proposed recently by Ju et al. (2011a, b).

fn.p: Figures 1–4 appear in color online: ijd.sagepub.com

We express our gratitude to Dr. Pai-Chen Guan for his assistance in implementing the proposed models into the Nonlinear Meshfree Analysis Program (NMAP) meshfree code by Chen (2001).
